Award.AwardTitle: US-China Summer School on Representation Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
Representation theory provides concrete models to study various symmetries in nature and has been a central theme in mathematics and physics. Many research groups world wide do research related to representation theory from various perspectives using different tools. Thus it is especially important that a graduate student working in this area has exposure to some of the breadth of the area. In order to strengthen graduate education in representation theory and help our graduate students gain international working experiences, a joint US-China Summer School on Representation theory will be held at East China Normal University in Shanghai during July 12-26, 2010. The program will feature five short courses given by leading experts on quantum affine algebras and Kac-Moody algebras.

This proposal provides travel supports for a group of US graduate students to attend a 2-week Summer School program in East China Normal University, Shanghai, China, as well as the international workshop at the end of the summer school. In the allocation of travel funds we will give preference to women and other minorities and underrepresented groups. The summer activities will strengthen the graduate education of US students in representation theory by providing unprecedented opportunities for them to gain insights on the mathematics, and it will also provide them with a wealth of international working experiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant provided partial support for 13 American students to attend the first joint US-China graduate summer school on quantum groups and representation theory held in East China Normal University, Shanghai during July 11 to 26, 2010.  The joint summer school is the first kind in this magnitude, with great suppor from Chinese sponsors who provided full support to 5 principal lecturers: Profs. Chari (Riverside), Y. Gao (York),  S. Kang (Seoul), O. Mathieu (Lyon), , R. Zhang (Sidney), Each lecturer gave 8 hour short courses on various topics in representation theory of Lie algebras, quantum groups and related topics. At the end of the summer school, a workshop was organized where experts and young researchers gave surveys on most recent results in the field.

American students from NCSU, Berkeley, Columbia, UC Riverside and UC Santa Cruz attended all activities. They also took the opportunity to visit the Shanghai Expo and engage in research discussion with their Chinese, Korean cohorts. The activities enjoyed support from Natural Science Foundation of China, East China Normal University and Shanghai Municipal Government.

The organizing committee consists of Naihong Hu, A. G. Helminck and Naihuan Jing, who was the field mentor for graduate students.

Prof. Naihuan Jing and Naihong Hu are also planing to edit a book of the lecture notes so more students and young researchers can benefit from the short courses.
